Relationships[]

Myra Castellanos[]

"Myra... What an incredible woman. She really could do it all..."

―Sebastian

Sebastian met Myra on the job, and was smitten with her. After she is injured in the line of duty, Sebastian confesses how he feels to her, which she admitted to reciprocating. The pair began a relationship, which eventually lead to marriage, and a daughter they named Lily. Sebastian was shown to be a loving husband to Myra, albeit somewhat negligent as he worked hard.

Sebastian thinks very highly of her. He sees her as an amazing detective, and later on mother. He mentions often how in awe he is of her capabilities and perseverance, and tends to prop up her skills and abilities as far greater than his.

After the fire that apparently killed Lily, Myra came to Sebastian claiming that Lily was still alive, having been kidnapped by a mysterious orginization. Sebastian tries to claim she needs rest and needs to accept Lily is gone. Myra eventually disappears, leading to Sebastian falling into a deep depression and turning to drink.

Upon discovering Myra was right about Lily being alive he deeply regretted not having more faith in his wife. When he discovered that she was still alive, he did everything he could to apologise and reason with her to come home.

At the end, he shows full respect and understanding for Myra's decision of staying behind, listening to her and going through with the plan despite his reluctance in losing her again.

Lily Castellanos[]

Sebastian cared deeply for Lily, doting on her every chance he got. After the fire that apparently claimed her life, Sebastian became deeply depressed, which was only further increased when his wife also disappeared. He was haunted by his failure to save her, causing him to begin drinking heavily.

Upon discovering that Lily was still alive, he agreed to reenter STEM in order to save her.

Joseph Oda[]

"Krimson City needs more men like him on the force and it’s an honor to be working with him."

―Sebastian, writing about Joseph

Despite initially being optimistic about working with Joseph, Sebastian's slow descent into alcoholism has turned their partnership sour. Concerned with Sebastian’s safety, Joseph filled a report to Internal Affairs, which saved Sebastian his job, but created an emotional rift between them.

During the events of the game, Sebastian shows dedication in protecting Joseph, going so far as to put Joseph's well-being above his. Despite the events of the past, the friendship that the two have is still very apparent.

Juli Kidman[]

"There’s something about her that gets under my skin but I can’t quite put my finger on it."

―Sebastian, writing about Kidman

Sebastian’s relationship with Kidman is strained. He is shown in an earlier memory to want to train her, insisting on it despite Joseph's warnings. However later on, presumably as he grew to know her, his opinion on the matter changed. He resents having to train her, going as far as to label it "babysitting duty." In his journal he describes her as being aloof and standoffish, even going as far as calling her a cold fish. Kidman also took issue with the aggressive way Sebastian went about working his cases, much to Sebastian’s annoyance.

But despite this, he does however show worry and concern for her while surviving together, showing that Sebastian does care for Kidman. Not only that but it's seen multiple times in the two-parter DLC's, that when Kidman sees memories that involve Sebastian in it, she says that he shouldn't be involved and that him and Joseph don't have anything to do with this. This shows that Kidman cares for Sebastian and Joseph and she doesn't want them to get hurt.

There is a scene in both the main game and the Consequence where Sebastian meets up with her in the destroyed Krimson city. He saves her from multiple Haunted and they travel through other buildings together. They enter a room and Sebastian gets a "Ruvik Headache." Sebastian sees his reflection in the window and realizes he's turning into a haunted. He tries to warn her to stay away but lost control of himself. He quickly charges at Kidman. While he does, Kidman sees Ruvik behind him. Since she has a better grasp of the situation (thanks to her previous encounters with Haunted Joseph), she manages to shoot Ruvik causing him to disappear. With Ruvik's hold on Sebastian gone, he ends up passing out, Kidman sees that he's leaning unconscious on her with his head on her left shoulder. While in this state, he turns back into a normal person and Kidman lies him on the ground.

After this she leaves the room and locks the door behind her. Sebastian quickly wakes up and gets to his feet, he sees her on the other side of the door and he's angry because he thinks that she shot him. In an effort to keep him out of the way, she doesn't explain to him that she actually didn't shoot him, rather she says that she had no other choice and that she's going to leave him behind because Ruvik will use him to try and stop her. Later Kidman comes across the KCPD building and sees three memories. She learns about the tragic loss of Sebastian's daughter and his wife leaving him, which makes Kidman feel sorry for him and starts to show pity. After this when they meet again while she's about to shoot Leslie, she's unable to express this feeling while he is aiming a gun at her because she sees an illusion of The Administrator instead of him. She ends up makes their relationship even worse when she accidentally shoots Joseph.

They have another run-in later, when she's chasing Leslie. He tries to protect Leslie from her, he of course says he doesn't trust her since she shot both him and Joseph. She tries to explain that Leslie has to die in order for Ruvik not to get out. He however doesn't get a chance to understand before Ruvik arrives, Ruvik then turns Leslie into fluid and absorbs him into his consciousness.

Later at the end, when Kidman is brought back into the real world, she finds Sebastian still unconscious in the tub. She saves him from being captured by MOBIUS by saying that he's dead. She then tells him, that she owes him one and that she hopes he finds what he's looking for (Myra and the truth).

Ruvik[]

At first, Sebastian doesn't really seem to understand who or what Ruvik is, but as his adventure continues, he is slowly shown more and more about who Ruvik is, and what the man has done. Witnessing firsthand the death and rebirth of Ruvik's sister, Laura Victoriano, as well as the collapsing of the barn they played in and many of the critical interactions between him and Dr. Jimenez. Relentless in his mission to escape the nightmarish world, Sebastian is forced to dispatch many beings under Ruvik's control, some even being gruesome manifestations of his past. Ruvik would then be forced to reveal his presence while absorbing a stream of red blood cells emanating from the corpses of his defeated pawns, proceeding to vanish shortly after. In the beginning, Ruvik referred to Sebastian as "[his], to do with as he pleased", but upon realizing that Sebastian would not waver in determination, he began treating him as a legitimate threat, purposefully altering the environment to force Sebastian to take more perilous routes, and eventually attempting to deal with him himself on several occasions. Sebastian soon comes to understand just who the man is, learning how he got his nickname, and seeing what will happen if he captures Leslie. Towards the end, Sebastian shows no remorse for him, angrily yelling things at times such as "Trying to make me feel sorry for you?" or "You brought this upon yourself".

Marcelo Jimenez[]

After startling Sebastian and explaining that he escaped the crashed ambulance too, they travel with each other for a fairly short period of time, Jimenez primarily relying on Sebastian to protect him, as he is a "non-combatant". Sebastian mostly just goes along with whatever the hysterical old man says, cooperating with his plan to escape Elk River, and later aiding him in retrieving his runaway patient, Leslie. After one of his lectures, Sebastian mutters to himself under his breath, referring to the doctor as a "jerk". Dr. Jimenez leaves Sebastian in the dark about a lot of things, which Sebastian eventually catches on to. On one of the occasions in which Sebastian is teleported to Dr. Jimenez' laboratory, he is forced to hold him up at gunpoint to get him to reveal information, such as how the world is run by Ruvik's mind, and how they could potentially use Leslie as a means of escape. From then on, Sebastian is quite sceptical of most things the doctor tells him, especially after seeing some of the flashbacks of him and Ruvik's past. When the Amalgam Alpha appears in Dr. Jimenez' laboratory, Sebastian calls to him, telling him to run, showing that he at least cared a little for the man.

Leslie Withers[]

Sebastian pursues Leslie for the majority of the game, the patient constantly on the move. When Sebastian is able to stop the boy, he usually panics or escapes. Sebastian first introduces himself to Leslie in a cave nearby the shack where he battled Connelly. Leslie, later on, comes to recognize Sebastian as a nice person, referring to him by his name, guiding him, helping him out of a locked room, and even going to him for help when Juli is chasing him. Sebastian first responds to Leslie's panicked demeanor in irritation and confusion, muttering things like "what the fuck?" or "what's wrong with this kid?". However, Sebastian later comes to realize just how important the boy is, and goes out of his way to protect him at all costs. He thanks Leslie when he is able to help him out of a locked room, and calling out to him in defeat when Leslie accidentally activates a barrier between the two in Chapter 7. When Juli tries to kill the boy, Sebastian holds a gun up to her, bent on keeping him alive. When Leslie walks up to Ruvik and is reduced to brain goo, Sebastian screams in horror, showing that he knew the boy was vital, and that he presumably cared for him a little bit, despite them rarely being with one another for extended periods of time.

Oscar Connelly[]

Sebastian's relationship with Connelly is not heavily explored, but they do seem at least get along fairly well. While driving to the asylum, Sebastian appears willing to listen to Connelly's theories about what awaits them there, even though Connelly is simply a patrol officer and not a detective.

After Connelly turns into a Haunted, Sebastian is shocked and horrified, showing that he did care for Connelly.

Tatiana Gutierrez[]

Despite being one of the few entities in STEM not hostile towards him, Sebastian was initially confused by her presence and emotionless personality. Because she is the sole caretaker of the Safe Haven, however, Sebastian slowly comes to see her as an ally in his quests. Near the end of The Evil Within 2, Sebastian thanks her for being there for him during both of his journeys in STEM.

Stefano Valentini[]

Initially, Sebastian didn't know who Stefano was as a person; however, as he traversed deeper into the bowels of Union he came to realize just how disturbed the photographer was, being violently thrust into all manner of scenarios mired in Stefano's so-called "artwork", always involving either a facet of one's countenance during the final moment before their death, or a mutilated semblance of body parts that he likened to sculptures. Sebastian held an immense disgust for Stefano, gradually worsening with every murder he witnessed, from cases he himself investigated during his time at KCPD, to the actresses lives that gave birth of one of Stefano's most prized works, Obscura, a camera and papier-mâché clad creature with limbs melded in, among many others. Sebastian's hatred for Stefano peaks when he stands by helplessly as he blows the heads off of an entire audience of innocent prisoners, at least one hundred. Furiously determined to save his daughter from the cruel fate Stefano devised for her in order to conduct his sinister hobby forever, he escaped the Aperture, confronting Valentini deeper within the Theater one last time, each of them fed up with the other's constant trickery. Sebastian defeats Stefano swiftly, and shoots the deranged serial killer in the eye with seemingly no remorse. Afterwards, when his photo is crossed off on Juli's bulletin, he even jokingly says "A giant, red 'X'. Now that's what I call art."

Theodore Wallace[]

From the moment Sebastian met Theodore, he held suspicions of him, primarily given the juxtaposition of flames and immolated bodies surrounding his sanctum to his otherwise calm demeanor. Upon refusing to accompany Theodore and waking up in a mysterious cabin after being drenched in blood, Sebastian's opinion of him hardly changes, and given his newfound knowledge of the Father's desire to gain control of Union, he discusses the matter with his compatriots, and deduces that he will have to be eliminated should he interfere again. Sebastian gains a newfound understanding of Theodore's mind-control abilities when he is forced to indirectly murder Liam O'Neal, and, as a result, his animosity towards him grows tenfold.

Upon a contrited Sebastian's return to Theodore's stronghold, he is met only with grisly and heavily reproachful imagery of his daughter conjured by Theodore himself. Dazed and confused, Sebastian is tricked into shooting Esmeralda in the stomach, later resulting in her becoming fatally wounded protecting Sebastian, who makes a recovery in Hoffman's safehouse, wrought with despair. Following an intense spiritual redemption, Sebastian ventures through Union, delves into the Bottomless Pit and scales Theodore's tower once more, this time prepared for everything Theodore can throw at him. Striking down many Disciples and Spawn along the way, Sebastian ascends to his throne room one final time, Wallace now threatening to murder his wife in front of his daughter. Hearing this, Sebastian furiously vows that he'll die before he lets such a fate befall them, and he plans on it.

Flustered by Sebastian's newfound resiliance to guilt-inducing visions, he recomposes himself, promptly entering Sebastian's memory and summoning manifestations of the most fearsome foes that he encountered at Beacon. Sebastian conquers his fears and dispatches each of them, teleporting them each back form the carnageous scenario, a dumbfounded Theodore stumbling backwards into the podium room where the two first met. Even after the murder of Liam O'Neal, betrayal to Myra, and what he supposedly intended to use Lily for, Sebastian, while furious, didn't shoot Theodore even as he had him at gunpoint, possibly indicating he had some mercy for the fanatic, though he never appeared particularly phased after Myra impaled him. When visiting a decrepit safehous in Limbo, Sebastian even makes a passing remark about how he believed the former motivational speaker to be in hell now.

Liam O'Neal[]

Liam is the first person he meets in STEM that is not one of the Lost. When they first meet, Liam threatens him with a handgun, Sebastian promptly putting his down and kicking it across the room. They talk about why Liam is in STEM, and Sebastian notices that Liam left the safety on. He then walks up to Liam, takes his gun, and tells him a real soldier would've turned the safety off. Liam trusts Sebastian, to an extent, but the two don't get along as well as they could due to the fact Sebastian thinks he's cowardly, and Harbinger Liam recalls this when he say, "I'm not weak anymore!"

Yukiko Hoffman[]

Sebastian is initially critical of the mysterious psychologist when she interrogates him in her safehouse at gunpoint, though after several discussions between the two, he begins to warm up to her, occasionally even cracking jokes together, a lighthearted change of pace from her otherwise icy and serious personality during their adventures. By the time the two had realized they were the last survivors within STEM, they had each bonded to the point where they went out of their way to protect each other, Hoffman eventually even giving her life to save him, much to Sebastian's sorrow.

Julian Sykes[]

Should the player decide to save him from the mob of Lost, Sebastian is willing to help Sykes with his plan to escape from STEM by traversing the dank corridors of the Marrow to re-activate a set of servers, in exchange for Sykes' agreeing to unlock all of the orange chests throughout the Business District. Later, before Sebastian sets out for Theodore's stronghold, Sykes contacts him once again, this time asking him to secure the area surrounding the STEM bath in question, this time in exchange for instructions on a backup method of escaping Union with Lily. Sebastian is reluctant to let Sykes risk his life like this, due to the trusty partnership the two had formed. When Sebastian finds out that Sykes only had a 1 in 4 chance of leaving STEM through the bath, he maintains an optimistic outlook and claims that he might have made it out alive safely.

Esmeralda Torres[]

Unlike the vast majority of the MOBIUS staff, Sebastian actually treats Torres with a fair level of respect and trust, which doesn't change even after he learns that she was the culprit behind the fire that destroyed his family home and resulted in the kidnapping of his daughter. Torres and Sebastian have a good team dynamic and chemistry, and he certainly sees her as a valuable ally, which makes him feel deeply horrified when he learns that her death was partly because of him, and vows to avenge her death by killing Theodore Wallace.

The Administrator[]

While certainly lacking the background that Kidman and him share, Sebastian does briefly meet the Administrator in The Evil Within 2, being brought into the advanced STEM room after Kidman tranquilized him in the bar. Though their interaction is brief, it is integral to the plot, as without the Administrator's manipulative offer, Sebastian wouldn't have re-entered STEM in the first place. After being briefed on what has happened to his daughter, and how the new STEM came to be, he enters, his last image before entering being The Administrator looking down on him through a window, striking his classic pose. After Sebastian leaves STEM, he pays no real thought to what happened to the Administrator, Kidman likely explaining at a later time.

Trivia[]

Sebastian's last name of Castellanos is a surname of Spanish origin, thus hinting at a Hispanic ancestry. The surname's roots could be traced back to its late Latin form of castellum, meaning "castle", and a "castellan" is a lord or governor of a castle district and overall a person of authority, which fits well with Sebastian's occupation as a senior police detective.

In the earlier drafts of the script where the game was supposed to take place in Spain, Sebastian was conceived as a native Spanish whose first name has a distinctively Hispanic pronunciation (Sebastián with an accent on the last syllable) before the diacritics were dropped in the final release.

In an earlier concept, Sebastian was among the people who set the barn Ruvik and Laura were playing in ablaze. The story was ultimately changed, however, as the developers wanted the audience to sympathize with the protagonist.

Also mentioned in The Art of The Evil Within, Sebastian originally had no daughter, and the source of his depression was from the passing of his wife, who weren't given much characterisation at all in the concept drafts.

The trench coat Sebastian wears at the very beginning of the first game was given to him by his wife, Myra. It is mentioned in the artbook that he feels its loss is significant to the events taking place.

He can be seen wearing his trench coat during the reveal trailer for The Evil Within 2. However, he doesn't wear the coat during the game at any point, instead wearing a canvas jacket prior to being approached by Kidman.

The trench coat is seen hanging on a coat stand in Sebastian's Room inside his office.

Sebastian is implied to be an old-fashioned policeman, as he still favors the old service revolver, even though most of his department have switched to semi-automatic pistols by the time the first game took place. While he does carry one of the latter for emergencies, his sidearm of choice is a revolver and his shoulder holster is one made for a six-shooter. The description of the revolver from the second game all but confirms this to be the case.

He started smoking at some point after joining the KCPD. After escaping from the Sadist in Chapter 1, he pulls a pack of cigarettes out of his vest, only to throw it away moments later when he realizes that it was empty. He later utilizes matches against The Haunted.

His drink of choice is whiskey, since he mentions it specifically in one of his journal entries.

According to a newspaper clipping, Sebastian used to live (and possibly still does) in the Park Ridge neighbourhood of Krimson City.

Sebastian uses reading glasses, as they can be found on his office desk in the KCPD flashback Juli Kidman witnesses.

In The Evil Within 2, due to leftover game assets, PC players can enable/disable a pair of glasses on Sebastian.

Thematically, Sebastian and Juli's mode of saving progress seems to relate to things that are considered to be "bad omens". For Sebastian, to enter Safe Haven and his room, he has to enter it through a broken mirror. For Juli, to save her progress she sits on a leather couch with a black cat.

Sebastian is considered to be a stereotypical hardboiled detective in-universe, as pointed out by Kidman in The Consequence. He drinks, smokes, wears a coat and is very hard-boiled personality-wise, all traits associated with these kinds of detectives.

In his journal, Sebastian admits to believing that you sometimes have to "bend the rulebook a bit" to break a case. This apparently put him at odds with Juli Kidman, who he thought was opposed to such tactics.

In an ironic twist of fate, it was revealed in the Kidman DLCs that Kidman was a juvenile delinquent before MOBIUS took her in. In The Evil Within 2, Sebastian remarks that Kidman would've made a great detective, to which she refutes.

In The Evil Within 2, Sebastian's more light-hearted moments, like the ones in the Shooting Range, gives a good idea of how he could have been like in his early years, if his journal entries and flashbacks are anything to go by.

The reveal trailer for The Evil Within 2 depicts the burning house scene from the prologue with Sebastian wearing his default attire instead of the unlockable Professional outfit as in the game proper.

The main promotional cover for The Evil Within 2 depicts Sebastian's wedding ring as gold, instead of silver.

Sebastian's old model from the first game is reused in the sequel during the segments where he has to revisit a mental recreation of Beacon Mental Hospital. It also appears in several Photographic Slides along with the pre-art shift model of Juli Kidman, though this use is inconsistent, given how Sebastian is depicted using the new model in specific slides.

Despite being a supposedly seasoned police detective, Sebastian still handles most of his sidearms with an improper "teacupping" stance in the first game. While this seems to have been mostly rectified by him switching to a more tactical Weaver stance in the sequel, he still aims the Revolver with his arm outstretched.

Sebastian's exact birthdate can be confirmed in The Consequence, shown briefly towards the end on the STEM terminal hooked up to his bath before Juli frees him.

In the first game, visible on the back of Sebastian’s left hand appears to be the faded remnants of an old tattoo. In gameplay, from different angles and lighting conditions, (as well as in certain in-game cutscenes), the speculated tattoo can be clearly seen. In the game’s Model Viewer, under “Sebastian Castellanos” and “Sebastian Castellanos (Trench Coat)”, the tattoo can actually be zoomed-in-on and examined from different angles. The tattoo itself possibly seems to be of a symmetrical design, set in black ink, and is visible starting from his left wrist and degrading in clarity as it reaches his knuckles. The design, meaning, origin and condition of the tattoo are never explained or even mentioned in the game’s narrative.
